Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Wireless Driver Alert System; A Vehicle to Roadside Unit Communication System
Award.AbstractNarration:
Broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is summarized as follows. (1) Social impact: Transportation is the bloodstream of this nation with its level of importance being second to water. This country?s roadways are public use and the PI?s proposed technology is aimed at maintaining a fair and unbiased information infrastructure that satisfies the needs of both automotive and government agencies to fulfill their roles in public use and safety. (2) Commercial impact: The ability for vehicles to identify roadside regulations and guidance will provide several beneficial factors that will help alleviate driver distraction while aiding in additional cognitive awareness and safety. Additionally, wireless capable road signs can provide additional resources than their static counterparts that will make them more attractive and cost effective to their responsible entity/agency. (3) Technical impact: The project pushes the abilities of ultra low powered devices to extend the idea of location services, thus location dependent information is stored at its source producing almost instantaneous availability.

The proposed project is working on further advancing and refining a small electronic device with wireless capabilities known as a roadside unit to meet the regulations of the United States Sign Council (USSC) motorist reaction distance for visual street cues to facilitate safe vehicle responses. Satisfying this requirement involves a novel communication protocol structured around efficient message transmission at ultra-low operating power to quickly detect and respond to moving vehicles with minimal energy usage. The projects communication protocol is designed to use minimal power while maximizing the amount of data throughput to ensure an operational lifespan of a battery powered device for a minimum of 10 years while achieving significant transmission distance. Because roadside infrastructure is standardized there is an opportunity for advanced data management techniques to simplify data transmission and decoding. The proposed system integrates and enhances the current vehicle-to-vehicle (V2V) communication platform by offering another layer of sophisticated physical object identification. As vehicles take on autonomous responsibilities, they?ll need reliable, accurate, and authenticatable information about their surroundings with enough notice to facilitate safe responses.

POR.DRECONTENT:
SinWaves Phase I proposal of A Vehicle to Roadside Communication System was aimed at providing evidence that an ultra-low power roadside communication network is feasible of transmitting street sign information to vehicles for driver awareness. The goals of this grant were to test the designed system in a known environment where system measurements can be matched to theoretical metrics. SinWaves identified several required tasks for realizing the roadside network. First SinWaves needed to design a low power device capable of living along the side of the road. Second, small digital identities needed to be developed for wireless street sign recognition. Finally, since street signs are electrically reflective it was hypothesised that signal directionally and quality would be improved if the antenna is placed appropriately in front of a street sign. Thus SinWaves architecture relies on being able to transmit the smallest amount of data in the shortest amount of time using the least amount of power and utilizing the environment to increase wireless signal quality.

The work performed can be broken down into two time periods, January to March and April to June. The first three months of the grant were spent on the development of the first roadside unit (RSU). During this time SinWaves spent a lot of time developing the printed circuit board assembly (PCBA) and constructing the sign identity lookup table. Throughout the duration of the award the identity lookup table required only 1 revision which was to increase the amount of GPS position precision. The second three months were dedicated to the continual test and iteration of the roadside unit. Many firmware variations and revisions were written to test different transmission characteristics and power management techniques. Data shows that week after week SinWaves was able to increase the communication performance of the system. Some of these revisions cut listening time to save power and although it increased the operating life of the RSU it negatively affected the RSU’s response rate. This logic requires more tuning. There exists documentation supporting that if the vehicle side beacon is adjusted the RSU miss rate will decrease. SinWaves developed a second RSU PCBA and due to manufacturing issues didn’t get it into the field until the last week of on campus testing. The data collected from this week shows that the new board’s wireless performance over distance is superior to the first.

The metrics used for judging the success of the system are the United States Sign Council’s Vehicle Reaction Distance and the American Association of State Highway and Transportation Officials Stopping Sight Distance. The subawardee recommended that stopping sight distance be used over vehicle reaction distance since it’s the transportation field’s design standard. Both metrics are based around human perception. RSU communication distance varied greatly depending on location and configuration. The results show that stopping sight distances up to 45 MPH are achieved. For signs that don’t require a vehicle to stop the communication range is shown to be acceptable. Data concludes that the wireless performance and transmission constiancy can be improved to meet the requirements of safe sign detection. Further testing is required to produce an acceptable confidence level that vehicles will consistently receive information only at distances appropriate for the specified sign maneuver.
